As our nation endures a public health emergency, some of the new coronavirus laws provide more funding for senior nutrition programs. @HHSGov has started to release $250 million in grants from the Administration for Community Living to help provide meals during this dire time.

I have championed the Meals on Wheels program for decades and helped in crafting the nutrition measures that will help older Kansans in communities big and small. As Chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, I will continue to focus on the needs of the hungry.

Some good news: Congress passed an updated Older Americans Act that supports Meals on Wheels. It also provides KS grants to support meal services at senior centers, community centers, schools, churches and senior housing complexes. It’s especially helpful to rural Kansans.

I am sorry to hear the news about Tom Coburn’s passing. He fought the battle against cancer for many years, just as he never stopped fighting for the people of Oklahoma and for our great country. Franki and I send our sympathies to his family.

This allows people with mild symptoms to stay out of the doctor’s office and treat symptoms at home with OTC medications more easily, which will help stop the spread of this dangerous virus.

Allowing patients to use their health savings account funds to purchase over-the-counter medications without getting permission from their doctors will help improve social distancing to combat the coronavirus.

I’m pleased the Coronavirus Phase 3 package includes both my Priority Zoonotic Animal Drug designation, along with the Restoring Access to Medication Act of 2019, my bill to ease the purchase of over-the-counter medications using health savings accounts.

Our brave servicemen and women deserve to have their legacy’s live on forever. This incredible story of Raymond Warren is a true inspiration on how we can honor those who have paid the ultimate price for our country.

Thanks to the DNA of a niece and nephew he never met, the remains of US Marine Reserve Pfc Raymond Warren have been identified decades after he was killed and buried in the Gilbert Islands during WWII.

The day US troops raised our flag at Iwo Jima is a day our nation & the world will never forget. The legacy of the brave men whose strength & sacrifice changed history will live on forever.
